revision.text: {{Talkheader}} {{ArticleHistory |action1=WPR |action1date=02:22, 29 April 2010 |action1link=Wikipedia:WikiProject Military history/Peer review/Siege of Fort William Henry |action1result=reviewed |action1oldid=358854599 |action2=GAN |action2date=23:13, 7 October 2010 |action2link=Talk:Siege of Fort William Henry/GA1 |action2result=listed |action2oldid=389413631 |action3=WAR |action3date=15:29, 17 January 2011 (UTC) |action3link=Wikipedia:WikiProject Military history/Assessment/Siege of Fort William Henry |action3result=approved |action3oldid=407485724 |dykdate=12 February 2010 |dykentry=... that some [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native Americans]] traveled up to {{convert|1500|mi|km}}, from as far away as the [[Mississippi River]], to participate in the 1757 '''[[Siege of Fort William Henry]]''' near [[Lake George (New York)|Lake George]], [[Province of New York|New York]]? |currentstatus=GA |topic=war }} {{WPMILHIST|A-Class=pass|class=A|B1=yes|B2=yes|B3=yes|B4=yes|B5=yes|old-peer-review=yes |French=yes|Early-Modern=yes|US=yes|British=yes}} {{WikiProject New York|class=GA|importance=low}} ==Last of the Mohicans== This battle is depicted in the movie Last of the Mohicans (sp?) - in the movie, the French general appears to suggesting to the natives to attack the British after they leave the fort.[[Special:Contributions/75.154.236.150|75.154.236.150]] ([[User talk:75.154.236.150|talk]]) 00:28, 16 February 2008 (UTC) The movie is not historically accurate. Montcalm abhorred what the Natives did, and even attempted to get them to stop, near the end of the 'massacre' —Preceding [[Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[Special:Contributions/68.30.113.163|68.30.113.163]] ([[User talk:68.30.113.163|talk]]) 20:05, 12 April 2009 (UTC) ==request for peer review, Battle of the Thousand islands== [[Wikipedia:Peer review/Battle of the Thousand Islands/archive1]] :I Just finished up the main body of this article on a relitivly small engagemet of the French and Indian War. I'm hopeing a peer review will bring some suggestions on how the article can be improved and hopfully bring some more info on the subject. I'd like to see more info on some of the personalities that don't have they're own page to link to, and some more detail on how the battle developed... Any input would be very much appreciated! Mike McGregor (Can) 18:13, 10 January 2006 (UTC) ==Conflicting sentences== -Munro eventually gave in after being shown an intercepted message from General Webb, the commander of British forces in the New York colony, which said that he would be unable to send reinforcements to relieve the beleaguered garrison. -General Webb did in fact send reinforcements to Fort William Henry, which arrived one day too late, Does this mean that the message was a ploy? Perhaps it should say "forged message?" colonel munro was very easily tricked into leaving the fort if he was a smart general he would have anticipated this trick by the french.you can understand that he saw how many troops the french and their native allies had plus they knew the terrain well.he should have stayed at the fort and tried to wait it out because the british obviously saw the importance of the fort, so how could munro not see this? ==I'd like to add a lot of info on this fort== I was fortunate to work on excavations around Fort William Henry, actually the incomplete Fort George, back in the very late 1990s and early 2000. I have many sources on Fort William Henry and the battle itself. The sources are mostly written by David Starbuck who oversaw some excavations within the reconstructed fort in the 1990s. However, I am a rather busy college student at the moment and I can't spare the time to put up much more than a few observations until this summer (6/2006). After that I'd be more than happy to contribute. [[User:ZenTrowel|ZenTrowel]] 03:52, 10 April 2006 (UTC) ==Battle or Siege?== Should the article be renamed to Siege of Fort William Henry? As that is what it literally was. There was very little fighting outside the Fort, except the massacre which was not really a battle.[[User:Lord Cornwallis|Lord Cornwallis]] ([[User talk:Lord Cornwallis|talk]]) 18:25, 16 January 2009 (UTC) :Yeah, that's a no-brainer, so I went ahead and renamed it. A Google Books search suggests that "siege of Fort William Henry" is about six times more common than "battle of...." —[[User:Kevin Myers|Kevin]] [[User talk:Kevin Myers|Myers]] 00:14, 26 November 2009 (UTC) {{Talk:Siege of Fort William Henry/GA1}} == how many eaten? == `in the French Preperations sections it states that "several" prisoners were ritualy eaten following the battle of sabbath day point, but on the battle of sabbath day point page it is specifically stated that "one unlucky prisoner" was eaten. i'm inclined to go with the latter but wtf do i know [[User:Primergrey|Primergrey]] ([[User talk:Primergrey|talk]]) 22:24, 6 September 2011 (UTC) :I'd be inclined to agree with you, because Parkman (cited here) isn't always right. However, William Nester quotes Bougainville on the matter ([http://books.google.com/books?id=YxFc_DoR0yIC&lpg=PA53&pg=PA54#v=onepage&f=false link]): "They put in the pot and ate three prisoners." Fowler refers to a different primary account that mentions only one victim. ''[[User:Magicpiano|Magic]]''[[User_talk:Magicpiano|♪piano]] 00:41, 7 September 2011 (UTC) sounds like maybe the sabbath day point page should be changed to "one or more" or something like that. i'll take it up over there [[User:Primergrey|Primergrey]] ([[User talk:Primergrey|talk]]) 00:45, 7 September 2011 (UTC)
